title: project title
text:
1 Introduction
Malaria is a life-threatening disease caused by infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. This analysis explores malaria cases from 2000 to 2017 globally and by regions (Americas, Africa, Eastern Mediterranean, Europe, South-East Asia, Western Pacific), focusing on trends in case numbers and death rates.

title: project title
text:
2.1 Research Question
How has global malaria cases and reported death cases changed over time and across different regions from 2000 to 2017?

title: project title
text:
2.2 Aims

To visualize trends in malaria cases and deaths globally from 2000 onwards.
To analyze regional differences and identify patterns or anomalies over time.
To better understand where malaria remains a major public health challenge.

title: project title
text:
2.3 Methodology


Dataset: WHO malaria data (reported cases and deaths by country and year).

Visualization Methods:

Scatter plots to show temporal trends.
Dynamic choropleth maps to demonstrate spatial changes.

title: project title
section: 4.1 Total Reported Malaria Cases Over Time
text:
4.1 Total Reported Malaria Cases Over Time

reported$Year <- as.factor(reported$Year)
reported %>%
  group_by(Year) %>%
  summarize(total_cases = sum(No..of.cases, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = total_cases, group = 1)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Total Reported Malaria Cases Over Time",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Total Cases") +
  theme_minimal()

title: project title
section: 4.2 Distribution of Reported Malaria Deaths by Year (Global)
text:
4.2 Distribution of Reported Malaria Deaths by Year (Global)

reported %>% 
  drop_na(No..of.deaths) %>% 
  mutate(Year = as.factor(Year)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = No..of.deaths)) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = "#56B4E9", alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Reported Malaria Deaths by Year (Global)",
       y = "Number of Deaths", x = "Year") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: project title
section: 4.3 Reported Malaria Deaths Over Time by Region
text:
4.3 Reported Malaria Deaths Over Time by Region

reported %>% 
  drop_na(No..of.deaths) %>% 
  mutate(Year = as.factor(Year)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = No..of.deaths)) +
  geom_point(color = "#D55E00", alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Reported Malaria Deaths Over Time by WHO Region",
       y = "Number of Deaths", x = "Year") +
  facet_wrap(~ WHO.Region, scales = "free") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: project title
section: 4.4 Total Reported Malaria Deaths Over Time by Region
text:
4.4 Total Reported Malaria Deaths Over Time by Region

# ðŸ“ˆ Line graph of deaths over time by WHO Region
reported %>% 
  drop_na(No..of.deaths) %>% 
  group_by(WHO.Region, Year) %>%  # <-- group by region and year
  summarize(total_deaths = sum(No..of.deaths, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = total_deaths, color = WHO.Region, group = WHO.Region)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) +
  geom_point(size = 2) +
  labs(title = "Reported Malaria Deaths Over Time by WHO Region",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Total Reported Deaths",
       color = "WHO Region") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'WHO.Region'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
â„¹ Please use `linewidth` instead.

title: project title
section: 4.5 Reported Cases by Country Over Time
text:
4.5 Reported Cases by Country Over Time

malaria_clean <- reported %>%
  select(Country, Year, `No..of.cases`) %>%
  rename(
    country = Country,
    year = Year,
    cases = `No..of.cases`
  )


library(plotly)


Attaching package: 'plotly'


The following object is masked from 'package:ggplot2':

    last_plot


The following object is masked from 'package:stats':

    filter


The following object is masked from 'package:graphics':

    layout

fig <- plot_ly(
  data = malaria_clean,
  locations = ~country,
  locationmode = 'country names',
  z = ~cases,
  text = ~paste(country, "<br>Cases:", cases),
  type = 'choropleth',
  frame = ~year,
  colorscale = 'Reds',
  marker = list(line = list(color = "gray", width = 0.5))
)

fig <- fig %>%
  layout(
    title = "Reported Malaria Cases Over Time",
   geo = list(showframe = FALSE,
               showcoastlines = FALSE,
               showcountries = TRUE,
               countrycolor = "gray",
               projection = list(type = "equirectangular"),
               bgcolor = "white",
               landcolor = "white")
  )

fig

title: project title
section: 4.6 Reported Deaths by Country Over Time
text:
4.6 Reported Deaths by Country Over Time

# Install and load countrycode package if not already installed
if (!require(countrycode)) {
  install.packages("countrycode")
}

Loading required package: countrycode

library(countrycode)

library(tidyverse)
library(plotly)

# Example: cleaning reported data
reported_clean_2 <- reported %>%
  mutate(
    country = countrycode(Country, origin = "country.name", destination = "iso3c")
    # year = as.integer(Year),
    # deaths = as.numeric(No..of.deaths)
  ) %>%
  filter(!is.na(country)
         # !is.na(year),
         # !is.na(deaths)
  )

# Create animated choropleth plot
fig <- plot_ly(
  data = reported_clean_2,
  type = "choropleth",
  locations = ~country,         # ISO3 codes
  z = ~No..of.deaths,           # Coloring by deaths
  frame = ~Year,                # Animation frame by year
  colorscale = "Reds",
  text = ~paste(Country, "<br>Deaths:", No..of.deaths),
  colorbar = list(title = "Deaths"),
  reversescale = FALSE
)

fig <- fig %>%
  layout(
    title = "Reported Deaths by Country Over Time",
    geo = list(
      showframe = FALSE,
      showcoastlines = FALSE,
      showcountries = TRUE,
      countrycolor = "gray",
      projection =list(type = "equirectangular"),
      bgcolor = "white",
      landcolor = "white"
    )
  )

fig

Warning: Ignoring 269 observations

title: project title
section: 4.7 Malaria Cases and Deaths by Country Over Time
text:
4.7 Malaria Cases and Deaths by Country Over Time

malaria_clean <- reported %>%
  select(Country, Year, `No..of.cases`, `No..of.deaths`) %>%
  rename(
    country = Country,
    year = Year,
    cases = `No..of.cases`,
    deaths = `No..of.deaths`
  )


fig <- plot_ly() %>%
  add_trace(
    data = malaria_clean,
    type = "choropleth",
    locations = ~country,
    locationmode = "country names",
    z = ~cases,
    frame = ~year,
    colorscale = "Blues",
    reversescale = TRUE,
    text = ~paste("Country:", country,
                  "<br>Total Cases:", format(cases, big.mark = ","),
                  "<br>Deaths:", format(deaths, big.mark = ",")),
    hoverinfo = "text",
    colorbar = list(title = "Total Cases"),
    marker = list(line = list(color = "white", width = 0.5))
  ) %>%
  

  add_trace(
    data = malaria_clean,
    type = "scattergeo",
    locations = ~country,
    locationmode = "country names",
    frame = ~year,
    marker = list(
      size = ~sqrt(deaths) * 0.25,
      color = 'red',
      opacity = 0.6,
      line = list(width = 0)
    ),
    hoverinfo = "none",
    showlegend = FALSE
  ) %>%
  
  # Layout
  layout(
    title = "Global Malaria Cases and Deaths from 2000 to 2017",
    geo = list(
      showframe = FALSE,
      showcountries = TRUE,
      showcoastlines = FALSE,
      countrycolor = "grey",
      landcolor = "lightgrey",
      projection = list(type = "equirectangular"),
      bgcolor = "white"
    )
  )

fig

Warning: Ignoring 234 observations


No scattergeo mode specifed:
  Setting the mode to markers
  Read more about this attribute -> https://plotly.com/r/reference/#scatter-mode

title: project title
text:
4.8 Future Work and Questions

Explore causes behind regional differences (e.g., healthcare access, climate, interventions).
Update the dataset with more recent years.
Investigate specific country case studies for deeper insights.
Analyze the relationship between malaria interventions and case/death trends.

title: 2Â  Feride K
text:
https://www.atlassian.com/blog/teamwork/the-importance-of-teamwork

2.0.1 Summary: The Importance of Teamwork (As Proven by Science)
Research shows that teamwork isnâ€™t just good for business, it boosts innovation, happiness, personal growth, and resilience across the board. With the rise of virtual work, collaboration has become even more essential.
Teamwork leads to:

Better problem-solving: Groups outperform individuals by combining skills and perspectives.
More innovation: Diverse teams unlock creativity and breakthrough ideas.
Happier employees: Honest, respectful teams boost emotional well-being and productivity.
Personal growth: Feedback and cross-training within teams help individuals improve and learn about themselves.
Reduced burnout: Sharing work and emotional support among teammates protects against stress.
Opportunities for growth: Teams solve complex problems better because no one person can know everything.
Higher productivity: Peer respect is a stronger motivator than manager approval.
Smarter risk-taking: Team support encourages bold, innovative ideas, especially in smaller groups.
Fewer mistakes: Supportive, low-stress teams make fewer errors.
Increased creativity: Open communication and trust allow new ideas to flourish.
Ultimately, teamwork creates stronger individuals, better companies, and smarter solutions to todayâ€™s complex challenges.

# Load necessary libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(data.table)


Attaching package: 'data.table'

    hour, isoweek, mday, minute, month, quarter, second, wday, week,

# Set data directory
dir1 <- "../input/malaria-dataset/"

# Load datasets
estimated_numbers <- read.csv("../../data/archive 2/estimated_numbers.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
incidence <- read.csv("../../data/archive 2/incidence_per_1000_pop_at_risk.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
reported <- read.csv("../../data/archive 2/reported_numbers.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

# Merge reported and incidence datasets
data <- reported %>% 
  left_join(incidence, by = c("Country", "Year", "WHO.Region")) %>% 
  rename("No.of.cases" = "No..of.cases.x",
         "No.of.cases.per.1000.pop.at.risk" = "No..of.cases.y")

# Set plot size for better readability
options(repr.plot.width = 14, repr.plot.height = 10)

# Boxplot of global deaths by year (non-faceted)
reported %>% 
  drop_na(No..of.deaths) %>% 
  mutate(Year = as.factor(Year)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = No..of.deaths)) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = "#56B4E9", alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Reported Malaria Deaths by Year (Global)",
       y = "Number of Deaths", x = "Year") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))






# ðŸŸ  Scatter plot of deaths over time, faceted by WHO Region
reported %>% 
  drop_na(No..of.deaths) %>% 
  mutate(Year = as.factor(Year)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = No..of.deaths)) +
  geom_point(color = "#D55E00", alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Reported Malaria Deaths Over Time by WHO Region",
       y = "Number of Deaths", x = "Year") +
  facet_wrap(~ WHO.Region, scales = "free") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))







general trends- what is going on in this region

unique(reported$WHO.Region)

[1] "Eastern Mediterranean" "Africa"                "Americas"             
[4] "Europe"                "South-East Asia"       "Western Pacific"      



library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(data.table)

# Set data directory
dir1 <- "../input/malaria-dataset/"

# Load datasets
estimated_numbers <- read.csv("../../data/archive 2/estimated_numbers.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
incidence <- read.csv("../../data/archive 2/incidence_per_1000_pop_at_risk.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
reported <- read.csv("../../data/archive 2/reported_numbers.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

# Merge reported and incidence datasets
data <- reported %>% 
  left_join(incidence, by = c("Country", "Year", "WHO.Region")) %>% 
  rename("No.of.cases" = "No..of.cases.x",
         "No.of.cases.per.1000.pop.at.risk" = "No..of.cases.y")

# Set plot size
options(repr.plot.width = 14, repr.plot.height = 10)

# ðŸ“ˆ Line graph of deaths over time by WHO Region
reported %>% 
  drop_na(No..of.deaths) %>% 
  group_by(WHO.Region, Year) %>%  # <-- group by region and year
  summarize(total_deaths = sum(No..of.deaths, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = total_deaths, color = WHO.Region, group = WHO.Region)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) +
  geom_point(size = 2) +
  labs(title = "Reported Malaria Deaths Over Time by WHO Region",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Total Reported Deaths",
       color = "WHO Region") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'WHO.Region'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

â„¹ Please use `linewidth` instead.

library(sf)

Linking to GEOS 3.11.0, GDAL 3.5.3, PROJ 9.1.0; sf_use_s2() is TRUE

library(rnaturalearth)

estimated_numbers <- read.csv("../../data/archive 2/estimated_numbers.csv") 
incidence <-read.csv("../../data/archive 2/incidence_per_1000_pop_at_risk.csv")
reported <-read.csv("../../data/archive 2/reported_numbers.csv") #use this one

world <- rnaturalearth::ne_countries(scale = "medium", returnclass = "sf")


dim(reported)

[1] 1944    5

reported_clean <- reported %>%
  rename(deaths = No..of.deaths)   

map_data <- world %>%
  left_join(reported_clean, by = c("name" = "Country"))


ggplot(map_data) +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = deaths), color = "white", size = 0.1) +
  scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "plasma", trans = "log10") +
  facet_wrap(~ Year) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Reported Deaths by Country Over Time",
    fill = "Deaths (log scale)"
  )

Warning in scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "plasma", trans = "log10"): log-10
transformation introduced infinite values.

Warning: Ignoring 269 observations












Caption



This interactice choropleth map shows the number of reported deaths of malaria by countries from 2000 to 2017. Countries shaded in deeper red tones indicate higher death counts, while countries in paler or base colors report fewer or no deaths in a given year. All the coutries appearing with the base color are included in the dataset.

    data = malaria_clean,

      color = 'red',

      showframe = FALSE,

      showcoastlines = FALSE,
      countrycolor = "grey",

title: Appendix A â€” Proposal
text:
Your proposal will go here.

A.0.1 Number of Malaria Cases from 2010

Amy Yang, Riley Karatas, Aisling Li, Zora Shi
Malaria is a life-threatening disease caused by parasites that are transmitted to people through the bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. Due to the significance of the cause we will be analyzing malaria cases from 2010 to 2017 in terms of global distribution, as well as changes in case numbers and death rate.
1 graph+description/person below we will assign to each person
1 graph/class
Total cases vs time -> Total cases vs time vs countries â€“> Choropleth map accordingly

Total death cases vs time Total death cases vs time vs countries Choropleth map accordingly
Total cases vs death vs time (the conclusion would be global, not regional) Total cases vs death vs region (regional excluding time variable)

title: Appendix B â€” Case Study
text:
Your case study will go here.

Germanyâ€™s Multiparty System Unlike the U.S. two-party system, Germanyâ€™s Bundestag includes multiple significant parties. The chart shows that no party typically wins a majority, which necessitates coalition governments. CDU/CSU (center-right) and SPD (center-left) are the largest parties but have seen declining shares over time, making smaller parties like the Greens, FDP, and AfD increasingly relevant in coalition-building.
Party Ideology Distribution The ideological spectrum chart maps German parties from left to right. The Left (far-left) and AfD (far-right) anchor the extremes. SPD, Greens, and CDU/CSU are more centrist, though CDU leans conservative. The chart reveals that German political ideology is more left-leaning overall than U.S. counterparts â€” even the CDU is not as far right as American Republicans.
Voter Base by Region (East vs.Â West) A geographic map shows stark regional divides: The Left dominates in the former East Germany. CDU and SPD perform better in the wealthier West. AfD shows stronger support in economically disadvantaged eastern regions, reflecting discontent. This highlights how historical and economic divisions continue to shape voter alignment decades after reunification.
